posts.title: Applying 'Atomic Habits' to Learning to Code
posts.content: I've been struggling to stay consistent with my Vue.js learning. I started applying the '2-minute rule' from James Clear's book. Instead of saying 'I will code for 2 hours', I just say 'I will open VS Code'. It's surprisingly effective.

social_mentions.content: You do not rise to the level of your goals. You fall to the level of your systems.

posts.title: Is 'Clean Code' still relevant in 2024?
posts.content: Uncle Bob's examples are in Java, and some people say the advice is outdated. However, I feel the core principles of meaningful naming and small functions are timeless. Thoughts?

social_mentions.content: Clean code is a myth. If it works, ship it. That's how you become a millionaire. (as a millionaire)

social_mentions.title: When you try to write clean code but end up with 50 classes

posts.title: The cozy beginning of The Hobbit
posts.content: Re-reading The Hobbit this weekend. I forgot how whimsical the opening chapter is compared to the epic scale of LOTR. Bilbo fretting over his doilies while Gandalf plots an adventure is peak comedy.

posts.title: Why you should master Vanilla JS before Frameworks
posts.content: Reading 'JavaScript: The Good Parts' reminded me why understanding closures and prototypes is crucial, even if you use React or Vue every day. Don't skip the basics, guys.

posts.title: HCI principles in modern Game UI
posts.content: I've been analyzing the inventory systems in RPGs. The principles from the 'Human-Computer Interaction' book regarding cognitive load are totally applicable here. Minimalist UI isn't just aesthetic; it's functional.

posts.title: MVP vs Polished Product
posts.content: The Lean Startup methodology saved my latest project. We were about to spend 6 months building a feature nobody wanted. 'Build-Measure-Learn' is the only way to go.

posts.title: Growth Mindset changed how I study
posts.content: I used to think I was just 'bad at math'. After reading Carol Dweck's book, I realized I just hadn't found the right method yet. It's a subtle shift but it changes everything.

posts.title: The math behind Deep Learning
posts.content: Finally diving into the 'Deep Learning' book by Goodfellow. The linear algebra chapter is dense but necessary. Anyone else working through this text?

posts.title: Design Patterns for Game Dev
posts.content: Observer pattern and Singleton are everywhere in Unity development. The Gang of Four book is dry, but the concepts are fundamental if you want scalable game architecture.

posts.title: PHP isn't dead, seriously.
posts.content: With Modern PHP practices and Laravel, the ecosystem is thriving. Stop hating on it if you haven't used it since 2010. 'Modern PHP' by Josh Lockhart is a great refresher.

posts.title: HTML semantics matter!
posts.content: Just finished Jon Duckett's HTML & CSS book. The visual explanation of the box model is the best I've seen. Beginners, please stop using divs for everything.

posts.title: Algorithms are hard.
posts.content: Donald Knuth's 'Art of Computer Programming' is intimidating. I treat it more like an encyclopedia than a reading book. Has anyone actually read it cover to cover?

posts.title: Habit Stacking for Readers
posts.content: Using Atomic Habits techniques: After I pour my morning coffee (current habit), I will read one page of a book (new habit). It's helping me get through my TBR pile.

posts.title: The Pragmatic Programmer is a career guide
posts.content: The advice about 'Stone Soup and Boiled Frogs' explains so much about corporate software development. It's not just code; it's about responsibility.

posts.title: Mental Models in Design
posts.content: Reading 'Design Patterns' made me realize we have similar patterns in UI. Users expect certain behaviors (like hamburger menus on mobile). Breaking these patterns causes friction.

posts.title: Mindset in Negotiation
posts.content: Fixed mindset says 'I am a bad negotiator'. Growth mindset says 'I can learn negotiation'. Dweck's research applies heavily to business strategy.

posts.title: Jump Fest 2025 Hype!
posts.content: Anyone else excited for the new shonen announcements? I'm hoping for some good fantasy adaptations, something with world-building like The Hobbit but anime style.

posts.title: Photography and Composition
posts.content: Just like in 'HTML & CSS', structure is everything. I'm trying to apply the rule of thirds from my design books to my weekend photography shots.

posts.title: AI generated code vs Clean Code
posts.content: Copilot is great, but it often violates 'Clean Code' principles. It repeats logic and creates massive functions. We still need to refactor AI output.

posts.title: Legacy Code Nightmares
posts.content: I inherited a project with zero comments and variables named 'x', 'y', 'temp'. 'Working Effectively with Legacy Code' is my bible right now, alongside 'Clean Code'.

posts.title: Vue 3 Composition API
posts.content: The new syntax in Vue 3 is so much cleaner. Reading 'Vue.js: Up and Running' helped bridge the gap from Options API for me.

posts.title: World Building 101
posts.content: Tolkien didn't just write a story; he created languages, maps, and histories. That's the standard for high fantasy. Any recommendations for books with similar depth?

posts.title: Database normalization
posts.content: Reviewing 'PHP and MySQL Web Development'. The chapter on database normalization is a great refresher. Many devs skip this and regret it later.

posts.title: Accessibility in Web Design
posts.content: Semantic HTML is the first step to accessibility. Screen readers rely on header tags and aria-labels. Duckett's book touches on this, but we need to go deeper.

posts.title: Pivoting your idea
posts.content: We realized our initial hypothesis was wrong. Following 'The Lean Startup', we pivoted instead of persevering on a dead end. Hard decision, but necessary.

posts.title: Dealing with burnout
posts.content: Programming is mentally exhausting. I'm using techniques from 'Mindset' to view this burnout as a signal to rest, not a sign of incompetence.

posts.title: Gaming marathons vs Habits
posts.content: I love gaming, but it eats my time. Trying to use 'Atomic Habits' to limit sessions to 2 hours. Identity shift: 'I am a gamer who also sleeps'.

posts.title: Neural Networks for Dummies
posts.content: Even if you are a web dev, understanding basic Neural Networks is becoming essential. The introductory chapters of 'Deep Learning' are approachable.

posts.title: DRY Principle in Design
posts.content: Don't Repeat Yourself isn't just for code. In UI design, using components (like in 'Pragmatic Programmer') saves so much time when clients ask for changes.

posts.title: History of Computing
posts.content: Reading Knuth's work gives you such an appreciation for the pioneers. Sorting algorithms we take for granted took years to perfect.

posts.title: CSS Grid is magic
posts.content: Remember float clearing? Dark times. Modern CSS is so powerful. If you are still using Bootstrap for everything, read a modern CSS book.

posts.title: Comfort characters
posts.content: Bilbo Baggins is the ultimate comfort character. He doesn't want to be a hero, he just wants his tea. Relatable.

posts.title: Factory Pattern use cases
posts.content: I used to think Design Patterns were academic fluff. Then I had to build a notification system supporting Email, SMS, and Push. Factory Pattern to the rescue.

posts.title: Forms are hard.
posts.content: Designing good forms is an art. 'Human-Computer Interaction' has a whole section on error recovery. Don't just show 'Invalid Error', tell users HOW to fix it.

posts.title: Validating assumptions
posts.content: The hardest part of 'The Lean Startup' is admitting you might be wrong. We utilize A/B testing for everything now.

posts.title: Consistency > Intensity
posts.content: Atomic Habits key takeaway: You don't rise to the level of your goals, you fall to the level of your systems. I'm building a system for my finals.

posts.title: Ethics in AI
posts.content: Deep Learning is powerful, but we need to talk about bias in datasets. Goodfellow touches on this, but it needs more discussion in our community.

posts.title: JS vs PHP for freelancing
posts.content: Hot take: PHP (Laravel) is still faster for whipping up a quick freelance project than a full JS stack. 'Modern PHP' proves it's robust enough.

posts.title: Affordances in real life
posts.content: After reading about HCI, I can't stop seeing bad design everywhere. Doors you pull but look like push doors (Norman Doors). Design matters!

posts.title: The mythical man-month
posts.content: Not on the list, but 'The Pragmatic Programmer' references it. Adding manpower to a late software project makes it later. Classic.

posts.title: State Management in 2024
posts.content: Vue's Pinia is so much simpler than Vuex. The 'Vue.js: Up and Running' concepts about state flow still apply, but the boilerplate is gone.

posts.title: Riddles in the Dark
posts.content: The chapter with Gollum in The Hobbit is a masterclass in tension. It's a children's book but that scene is genuinely creepy.

posts.title: Bad comments vs Clean Code
posts.content: Don't write comments that repeat the code. 'i++ // increment i'. Clean Code taught me that code should express itself. Comments are for 'Why', not 'What'.

posts.title: Color Psychology
posts.content: Discussing color theory in web design. It's not just CSS hex codes; it's about emotion. HTML & CSS covers syntax, but we need to study art too.

posts.title: Vanity Metrics
posts.content: Page views don't pay the bills. 'The Lean Startup' warns against vanity metrics. We focus on conversion and retention now.

posts.title: The power of 'Yet'
posts.content: I don't understand recursion... YET. That simple word from Dweck's 'Mindset' keeps me going when algorithms get tough.

posts.title: Gaming Community Toxicity
posts.content: We need better community management in esports. Maybe applying some 'HCI' social computing principles could help reduce toxicity in chat?

posts.title: Backpropagation explained
posts.content: The chapter on backprop in 'Deep Learning' is the best technical explanation I've found. It's just chain rule, but applied at scale.

posts.title: JavaScript weirdness
posts.content: Type coercion in JS is a nightmare. 'The Good Parts' suggests using === always. It's a simple rule that saved me so many bugs.

posts.title: Reading Code
posts.content: We spend more time reading code than writing it. That's the main takeaway from 'Clean Code'. Write for humans, not for the compiler.

books.title: lean Code: A Handbook of Agile Software Craftsmanship
books.author: Robert C. Martin
books.description: Even bad code can function. But if code isn't clean, it can bring a development organization to its knees. Every year, countless hours and significant resources are lost because of poorly written code. But it doesn't have to be that way.

Physical.description: Physical paperback/hardcover edition available at retail locations

sources.name: New York Public Library - Tech Collection

books.title: The Hobbit
books.author: J.R.R. Tolkien
books.description: Bilbo Baggins is a hobbit who enjoys a comfortable, unambitious life, rarely traveling any farther than his pantry or cellar. But his contentment is disturbed when the wizard Gandalf and a company of dwarves arrive on his doorstep one day.

Physical.description: Physical paperback/hardcover edition available at retail locations

books.title: Atomic Habits: An Easy & Proven Way to Build Good Habits & Break Bad Ones
books.author: James Clear
books.description: No matter your goals, Atomic Habits offers a proven framework for improving--every day. James Clear, one of the world's leading experts on habit formation, reveals practical strategies that will teach you exactly how to form good habits, break bad ones, and master the tiny behaviors that lead to remarkable results.

Physical.description: Physical paperback/hardcover edition available at retail locations

books.title: Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software
books.author: Erich Gamma, Richard Helm, Ralph Johnson, John Vlissides
books.description: Capturing a wealth of experience about the design of object-oriented software, four top-notch designers present a catalog of simple and succinct solutions to commonly occurring design problems.

Physical.description: Physical paperback/hardcover edition available at retail locations

sources.name: Books Inc - Opera Plaza
sources.address: 601 Van Ness Ave, San Francisco, CA 94102

books.title: The Pragmatic Programmer: Your Journey to Mastery
books.author: David Thomas, Andrew Hunt
books.description: Written as a series of self-contained sections and filled with classic and fresh anecdotes, thoughtful examples, and interesting analogies, The Pragmatic Programmer illustrates the best approaches and major pitfalls of many different aspects of software development.

Physical.description: Physical paperback/hardcover edition available at retail locations

books.title: Deep Learning
books.author: Ian Goodfellow, Yoshua Bengio, Aaron Courville
books.description: The text offers mathematical and conceptual background, covering relevant concepts in linear algebra, probability theory and information theory, numerical computation, and machine learning. It describes deep learning techniques used by practitioners in industry.

Digital.description: Free online edition with full access

Physical.description: Physical edition available through academic channels

books.title: The Lean Startup: How Today's Entrepreneurs Use Continuous Innovation
books.author: Eric Ries
books.description: Most startups fail. But many of those failures are preventable. The Lean Startup is a new approach being adopted across the globe, changing the way companies are built and new products are launched.

Physical.description: Physical paperback/hardcover edition available at retail locations

sources.name: Austin Public Library - Central
sources.address: 710 W Cesar Chavez St, Austin, TX 78701

books.title: Human-Computer Interaction
books.author: Alan Dix, Janet Finlay, Gregory D. Abowd, Russell Beale
books.description: Much has changed since the first edition of Human-Computer Interaction was published. Ubiquitous computing and rich sensor-filled environments are finding their way out of the laboratory, not just into movies but also into our workplaces and homes.

Physical.description: Physical paperback/hardcover edition available at retail locations

books.title: Mindset: The New Psychology of Success
books.author: Carol S. Dweck
books.description: After decades of research, world-renowned Stanford University psychologist Carol S. Dweck, Ph.D., discovered a simple but groundbreaking idea: the power of mindset. In this brilliant book, she shows how success in school, work, sports, the arts, and almost every area of human endeavor can be dramatically influenced by how we think about our talents and abilities.

Physical.description: Physical paperback/hardcover edition available at retail locations

books.title: The Art of Computer Programming
books.author: Donald E. Knuth
books.description: This multivolume work on the analysis of algorithms has long been recognized as the definitive description of classical computer science. The three complete volumes published to date already comprise a unique and invaluable resource in programming theory and practice.

Physical.description: Physical paperback/hardcover edition available at retail locations

books.title: PHP and MySQL Web Development
books.author: Luke Welling, Laura Thomson
books.description: Learn PHP and MySQL programming - the practical guide to developing dynamic web applications using PHP and MySQL database. This comprehensive book covers everything from basic PHP syntax to advanced database interactions, form processing, security, and modern best practices for building robust web applications.

Physical.description: Physical paperback/hardcover edition available at retail locations

twitter_embeds.text: Just finished PHP and MySQL Web Development - excellent resource for anyone starting with backend development! The database design chapters are gold. #PHP #WebDev
twitter_embeds.author: DevMaster

books.title: JavaScript: The Good Parts
books.author: Douglas Crockford
books.description: Most programming languages contain good and bad parts, but JavaScript has more than its share of the bad, having been developed and released in a hurry before it could be refined. This book scrapes away these bad features to reveal a subset of JavaScript that is more reliable, readable, and maintainable.

Physical.description: Physical paperback/hardcover edition available at retail locations

twitter_embeds.text: JavaScript: The Good Parts completely changed how I write JS. Every frontend developer should read this at least twice! #JavaScript #WebDev
twitter_embeds.author: FrontendGuru

books.title: Modern PHP: New Features and Good Practices
books.author: Josh Lockhart
books.description: PHP has transformed from a simple scripting language into a powerful, modern programming language capable of handling complex web applications. This book teaches you modern PHP features and best practices, covering namespaces, traits, generators, closures, and the latest PHP standards.

Physical.description: Physical paperback/hardcover edition available at retail locations

sources.name: PHP The Right Way
sources.description: Modern PHP best practices and standards

twitter_embeds.text: Modern PHP by Josh Lockhart is a game-changer for PHP developers. Shows how far PHP has come as a serious programming language! #PHP #ModernPHP
twitter_embeds.author: PHPSavant

reviews.review: This book completely changed how I write code. Every developer should read this - it's not just about writing clean code, it's about thinking like a software craftsman. The examples are practical and the principles have stood the test of time.

A timeless classic that transports you to another world. Tolkien's world-building is unmatched. The prose is beautiful, the characters are memorable, and the story is both epic and intimate. Essential reading for any fantasy lover.

Practical and actionable advice. Some concepts felt repetitive, but the overall framework is solid. I've already started implementing small habits and seeing results. Would recommend to anyone struggling with consistency.
Great book with solid principles, though some examples feel a bit dated. The core concepts are still relevant and have improved my code quality significantly. A must-read for any serious developer.

The GoF patterns are timeless classics. This book is dense but incredibly valuable. It's not something you read once - it's a reference you'll return to throughout your career. Essential for any software architect.

This book is worth its weight in gold. The practical advice and real-world examples make it immediately applicable. I've been programming for 10 years and still learned so much. Every developer should read this.

Comprehensive and well-written introduction to deep learning. The mathematical foundations are solid and the examples are clear. Can be quite dense at times, but worth the effort for anyone serious about ML.
Life-changing book! The 1% better every day concept is revolutionary. I've applied these principles to both my personal and professional life with amazing results. Highly recommended!
Interesting concepts but feels repetitive after a while. The lean methodology is valuable, but the book could have been more concise. Good for entrepreneurs but less so for established businesses.
Solid textbook for HCI students. Covers the fundamental concepts well with good examples. Some sections feel a bit dated given how rapidly the field evolves, but the core principles remain valuable.

Mindset changed my perspective on learning and growth. The distinction between growth and fixed mindset is powerful and has helped me overcome many self-imposed limitations. Should be required reading for educators and parents.

The bible of algorithms and computer programming. Knuth's writing is brilliant and the exercises are challenging but rewarding. This is not for beginners, but essential for anyone serious about computer science theory.

comments.text: The 2-minute rule is gold. I use it for gym too. Just putting on my shoes is the victory.
James Clear is a genius. Good luck with Vue!
Clean Code is timeless. The syntax changes, but humans reading code doesn't change.
Good morning! We don't want any adventures here, thank you! üßô‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
Crockford was right about a lot of things. 'This' binding in JS still confuses me sometimes.
Dead Space UI is the peak of HCI in gaming. No HUD, everything in the world.
Fail fast, fail cheap. Best advice I ever got.
The power of 'Not Yet' is real. Keep going!
It's heavy on probability theory too. Takes time to digest.
Just don't overuse Singletons! They make testing a nightmare.
Laravel is basically Rails for PHP. It's amazing.
Div soup is a crime against accessibility. Use <main>, <article>, <nav>!
It sits on my shelf to make me look smart. I read 50 pages and my brain hurt.
Habit stacking works! I do audiobooks while commuting.
Don't live with broken windows. Fix bad code as soon as you see it.
Jakob's Law: Users spend most of their time on other sites. Make yours work like they expect.
Negotiation is a skill, not a talent. 100% agree.
Hoping for a new arc announcement for One Piece!
The golden ratio is everywhere, in nature and in websites.
Copilot is a junior dev on steroids. Needs supervision.
I feel your pain. Refactoring that safely needs test coverage first.
Composition API is great for code reuse. Hooks are life.
Try 'Dune' if you want deep politics and ecology, or 'Wheel of Time' for scale.
Third Normal Form saves headaches. Redundant data is the enemy.
Accessibility helps everyone, not just those with disabilities. SEO loves it too.
Pivot or persevere. The hardest question in business.
Take a break. Your code will be better when you come back.
Identity based habits are powerful. 'I am a reader' vs 'I want to read'.
I'm still stuck on Gradient Descent concepts. Math is rusty.
Figma components are basically coding classes for designers.
Knuth is a legend. His dedication to TeX alone is inspiring.
Grid + Flexbox is the dream team. I barely touch media queries now.
And he stole the Ring! Sneaky hobbit.
Patterns are tools, not rules. Use them where they fit.
Inline validation is a must. Don't wait for submit to show errors.
Data doesn't lie, but our interpretation of it often does.
Systems > Goals. Goals have an end point, systems are for life.
Bias in AI is a reflection of bias in society. We need to curate data better.
Time to market is key. PHP wins there for small to mid projects.
Norman Doors! Once you see them, you can't unsee bad UX.
Nine women can't make a baby in one month. Brook's Law.
Pinia is a breath of fresh air. Goodbye mutations!
What have I got in my pocket?
Self-documenting code is the goal. Naming is the hardest part of CS.
Blue is trust, red is urgency. But culture context matters too.
Revenue and retention are the only metrics that matter.
Recursion clicks eventually. Draw out the stack frames!
Positive reinforcement systems works better than bans.
Calculus is the language of the universe (and AI).
Typescript fixes this. Just sayin'.
Code is poetry. Or spaghetti. Usually spaghetti.
